message_1: What is the age of the universe according to the theory of Relativistic Cosmology, taking into account the current estimate of the Hubble constant and assuming a flat universe?
message_2:
According to the theory of Relativistic Cosmology, the age of the universe can be estimated using the Hubble constant (H₀), which is a measure of the rate of expansion of the universe. The current estimate of the Hubble constant is about 67.4 km/s/Mpc (kilometers per second per megaparsec) as per the Planck mission results.

Assuming a flat universe, we can use the Hubble constant to estimate the age of the universe using the following formula:

Age of the universe = 1 / H₀

However, we need to convert the Hubble constant into the appropriate units of inverse time (1/seconds) before using it in the formula. To do this, we'll use the conversion factors:

1 Mpc = 3.086 × 10^19 km
1 km = 10^3 m
1 s = 3.154 × 10^7 yr (seconds per year)

First, convert the Hubble constant from km/s/Mpc to m/s/Mpc:

67.4 km/s/Mpc × (10^3 m/km) = 67.4 × 10^3 m/s/Mpc

Now, convert from m/s/Mpc to 1/s:

(67.4 × 10^3 m/s/Mpc) × (1 Mpc / 3.086 × 10^19 m) = 2.182 × 10^-18 1/s

Finally, calculate the age of the universe:

Age of the universe = 1 / H₀ = 1 / (2.182 × 10^-18 1/s)

Age of the universe ≈ 4.58 × 10^17 s

Now, convert the age of the universe from seconds to years:

Age of the universe ≈ (4.58 × 10^17 s) × (1 yr / 3.154 × 10^7 s) ≈ 14.5 billion years

So, according to the theory of Relativistic Cosmology and the current estimate of the Hubble constant, the age of the universe is approximately 14.5 billion years, assuming a flat universe.
